title: Define step properties
content:
This topic contains the procedures to create inputs and outputs for the steps of the native OO and CloudSlang flows, Python operations, and system properties.

Set up step input properties for a step 

Add a step input

Step inputs are defined for a single step of an operation or flow. To add and edit the inputs in a step.

  1. Click a step in the canvas.

  2. Click the Inputs tab, and then click Add a Step Input  . The new step input block is added. For example, input_0.
  3. Click the Select Value drop-down, and then enter appropriate values (constant or expression).
    Each step input has a value that can be set in the following ways:
    • A constant value.

    • A default value - as defined in the flow/operation that the step is based on.

    • A system property - system properties can be defined under Project > Configuration > System Properties. If you choose to define the value from a system property, the content pack or project from which the system property originates is displayed. An empty string value for a required step input is invalid.
    • A python expression.
    • A flow variable - flow variables can be defined in the flow inputs, as described in the "Set up inputs for the flow" topic. Flow variables can also contain published output data from steps in the workflow.
  4. Alternatively, click Edit Expression    to open Expression Editor window.
    1. Enter appropriate input values or functions into the step input.
    2. Click Save to save the input values.
    3. Click Cancel to return to the GRAPH view of the canvas.
  5. Click Save   from the canvas toolbar to save the step input.

Rename a step input

To rename a newly added input for a single step of an operation or flow:

  1. Select the step and then hover over its Step Input block. The highlighted step input block displays its toolbar.
  2. Double-click the Step Input block. The step input is enabled for editing.
  3. Click inside the Step Input name field, and then type a new unique name according to your choice. For example: From input_0 to input_1. If you enter an existing step input name, a red warning message is displayed to indicate a duplicate name.
  4. Click Save  in the canvas toolbar to save the new step input name.

The Step Inputs of the existing native or CloudSlang content pack flows and operations are not editable.

Set up an alternate input value for a step input

You can set up an otherwise option to a step input of a flow that uses a defined variable value as its input. During runtime, if the flow variable value does not exist or is empty, the value defined Add an Otherwise option is used for execution.
To set up an otherwise option to a step input:

  1. On the selected Step Input block, click Add an Otherwise option  . An Otherwise text field displays underneath the selected Step Input.
  2. From the Otherwise text field, click Select Value drop-down, and then select or enter appropriate values (constant or expression). You can assign the value from a flow variable, a constant, an expression, or a system property.
    You can also open the Expression Editor to add an otherwise (alternate) value.
  3. Click  to remove Add an Otherwise option from a step input.
  4. Click Save  in the canvas toolbar. The step input with an otherwise option is ready for execution.

The Add an Otherwise option  is enabled only when an Input is assigned a value from a System Property or a flow variable.

Set up a step input as sensitive

To set up a step input as sensitive:

Only a new custom step input is editable. The input text box of the step input having a dependency is set to a read-only state and is not editable.

  1. On the selected Step Input block, select the Sensitive input   check box next to the lock icon. The values of sensitive steps are replaced and displayed with asterisks in both the Input field and the YAML source. However, the existing values are cleared when a step input's sensitive state is removed.
    We encourage the customer to put only non-sensitive/private information in the relevant fields, which is not provided. By not implementing the suggestion you may be exposing the system to increased security risks. You understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same. It remains at all times the Customer’s sole responsibility to assess its own regulatory and business requirements. OpenText does not represent or warrant that its products comply with any specific legal or regulatory standards applicable to Customer in conducting Customer's business.
  1. Click Save  from the canvas toolbar to save the step input set as sensitive.

    Make sure your flows do not append sensitive variables to an already encrypted data set. OO only supports data units encrypted once, and cannot decrypt data resulting from multiple encrypted units combined.

Set up input prompts for a CloudSlang step

If you want to run a single flow with varying manual inputs, you can set up input prompts for a specific step. The steps can be debugged locally many times.

To set up input prompts:

  1. Select a CloudSlang flow, and then expand its Inputs tab.
  2. Set up input properties for the flow as described in Set up flow input properties topic.
  3. In the Inputs pane, hover over the Input parameters block. The block is highlighted with options to choose from.
  4. Click the input parameters drop-down , and then from the pop-up, select Input Variables defined in the PROPERTIES tab. 
  5. Double-click on the block, and then select the Prompt  . The Edit Prompt settings  gets enabled for the selected flow.
  6. Click Edit Prompt and then choose any one of the following options from the Prompt Settings dialog.
    1. None - use this if you do not want to set input prompts.
    2. Text - use this option to set a textual description for the input. The message entered will appear in the input field during the debug process.
    3. Single Selection - use this option to set a single input for selection during the debug process. You can add more than one input entry separated by delimiters to select one input during debugging.
    4. Multi Selection - use this option to set multiple inputs for selection during the debug process. You can add more than one input entry separated by delimiters to select multiple inputs at the time of debug.
  7. To define a step input as Text based prompt:
    1. In the Prompt Settings dialog, for the Message field, type in your preferred message. The message provided here appears underneath the input prompt at the time of debug.
    2. Click Set to save the Text prompt settings or Cancel to discard the settings.
  8. To define a step input as Single Selection based prompt:
    1. In the Prompt Settings dialog, select Single Selection. The available options for Single Selection appear.
    2. In the Options (mandatory) field, enter the list of values separated by a delimiter. The values entered here become available for selection at the time of debug.
    3. In the Delimiter field, enter the delimiter that you want applied for the values entered in Options field. You can use any characters for delimiters other than the default comma (,).
    4. In the Message field, type in your preferred message. The message provided here appears underneath the input prompt at the time of debug.
    5. Click Set to save the Single Selection prompt settings or Cancel to discard the settings.
  9. To define a step input as Multi Selection based prompt:
    1. In the Prompt Settings dialog, select Multi Selection. The available options for Multi Selection appear.
    2. In the Options (mandatory) field, enter the list of values separated by a delimiter. The values entered here become available for selection at the time of debug.
    3. In the Delimiter field, enter the delimiter that you want applied for the values entered in Options field. You can use any characters for delimiters other than the default comma (,).
    4. For the Message field, type in your preferred message. The message provided here appears underneath the input prompt at the time of debug.
    5. Click Set to save the Multi Selection prompt settings or Cancel to discard the settings.
  10. Alternatively, click    to open the Expression Editor window.
    1. Enter the custom text in the Code Editor pane, and then click Save.
  11. Press Ctrl+S or click SAVE  to save the flow. 

View inputs in a step that was created from another flow

If you include flow inputs in one flow (Flow A) and use this flow as a sub-flow step in another flow (Flow B), these inputs are available as step inputs for the step in Flow B.

You can also view the descriptions that were given to the flow inputs in the original flow (Flow A).

  1. Create a flow with flow inputs (Flow A), and provide the input properties defined in PROPERTIES tab.

  2. Create a second flow (Flow B) and use Flow A as its step.

  3. In Flow B, select that step input. In the Input Value drop-down, the Step Inputs of Flow A appear for selection.

  4. Hover a mouse over an input, and then click Info . The description of the original flow input is displayed.

Set up run ID to a CloudSlang step

You can set up a run ID as a global variable and bind it to CloudSlang's Step Inputs and Outputs to identify flow runs for debug purposes. This helps in solving flow execution errors using logs. 

The current release supports the run ID at the step level.

To set up run ID as a global variable in a CloudSlang flow:

  1. Open the CloudSlang flow from the PROJECTS tab.
  2. On the canvas, double-click the step. The Inputs and Outputs tabs expand on the canvas.
  3. Add a new Step Input and then click   to open the Expression Editor window.
    You can use the same procedure to set up run_id to a Step output.
  4. In the Code Editor pane, type the value run_id without using quotes, and then click Save.

    In the above image, [e] indicates the input as Expression.
  5. In the GRAPH view, you may choose to set the run_id for the Step Outputs as well.
  6. Press Ctrl+S or click SAVE to save the flow. 
  7. Execute the flow DEBUG locally. The debug results display a unique ID generated for the custom input you might have created to identify the flow.
    For example, in the following image, the my_run_id step input displays the unique ID (30001) for the flow csRunIDProj that uses add_numbers operation.

Delete a step input

You can delete a step input when:

  • You have created a new Step Input for a new flow, Python Operation, or System Property.
  • You have created a new Step Input for an existing OO native or CloudSlang flow, Python Operation, or System Property.

To delete a custom step input from a single step:

  1. Hover over the selected Step Input block. The step input toolbar displays.
  2. Click Delete  . The step input is removed, or edited values are erased based on the flow or operation type:
    1. The edited step input values of a dependent flow or operation are erased.
    2. The step inputs of a dependent flow or operation are set back to read-only state and cannot be deleted.

Set up step output properties for a step

Add a step output

Step outputs are defined for a single step of an operation or flow. To add and edit the outputs in a step.

  1. Select a step in the canvas. The Inputs and Output tabs for the step display.

  2. Click the Outputs tab, and then click Add a Step Output . Select the type of output from the drop-down. 
  3. On the Step Output block, click the Select Value drop-down, and then enter appropriate values (constant or expression).

    You can assign the value of an output from one of the following:

    1. Constants.
    2. Current step input.
    3. An Underline output - the most common use case is to use outputs received from an operation or flow.
    4. A system property - system properties can be defined under Configuration>System Properties, as described in the "Author system properties" topic.
    5. Directly edit the expression of a value using the Expression Editor.
    6. You can also extract and modify parts of an output using Python.
      For example, if you have a step that counts the number of servers that are online, this output is published as a flow variable, which can be added to an email that is sent to the system administrator.
  4. Alternatively, click Edit Expression    to open Expression Editor window.
    1. Enter appropriate output values or functions into the step output.
    2. Click Save to save the input values.
    3. Click Cancel to return to the GRAPH view of the canvas.
  5. Click Save   from the canvas toolbar to save the step output.

Rename a step output

To rename a newly added output for a single step of an operation or flow:

  1. Select the step and then hover over its Step Output block. The highlighted step output block displays its toolbar.
  2. Double-click the Step Output block. The step output is enabled for editing.
  3. Click inside the Step Output name field, and then type a new unique name according to your choice. For example: From output_0 to output_1. If you enter an existing step output name, a red warning message is displayed to indicate a duplicate name.
  4. Click Save  in the canvas toolbar to save the new step output name.

Set up a step output as sensitive

To set up a step output as sensitive:

  1. On the selected Step output block, select the Sensitive output   check box next to the lock icon. The values of sensitive steps are replaced and displayed with asterisks in both the Output field and YAML source. However, the existing values are cleared when a step output's sensitive state is removed. 
We encourage the customer to put only non-sensitive/private information in the relevant fields, which is not provided. By not implementing the suggestion you may be exposing the system to increased security risks. You understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same. It remains at all times the Customer’s sole responsibility to assess its own regulatory and business requirements. OpenText does not represent or warrant that its products comply with any specific legal or regulatory standards applicable to Customer in conducting Customer's business.
  1. Click Save  from the canvas toolbar to save the step output set as sensitive.

Delete a step output

You can delete a step output when:

  • You have created a new Step output for a new flow, Python Operation, or System Property.

To delete a custom step output from a single step:

  1. Hover over the selected Step Output block. The step output toolbar displays.
  2. Click Delete  . The step output is removed.

Publish outputs for a step

When setting up step outputs, you choose which information you want to use from the data that was received in the various flows and operations.

This output will be available to be used as input in other steps and is also available as a flow output.

Check for errors in a step

  • In the Authoring pane, if there is an error in a step operation, for example, missing information, the error appears with a red error flag in the top left corner.

    Click the error flag to display a tooltip with information about the error.
  • If there is a step with a missing dependency (for example, a step that is based on a flow that was deleted), that step appears with a gray, striped background.
  • In the GRAPH view, if there are fields with errors in the Inputs and Outputs tabs, these fields appear with an error flag.
  • The tabs at the bottom of the Step Properties pane also appear with an error flag, which includes a number, representing the number of errors. After you fix the errors, these error signs disappear.

Related topics

  • To define flow properties, see Define flow properties.
  • For instructions on authoring system properties, see Author System Properties.
  • To edit an expression of input and output using Expression Editor, see Edit the expression of a value for an input or output.
  • For instructions to extract and modify output values, see Extract and modify output values.
  • For instructions to create and deploy a content pack, see Create and deploy a content pack.
